questions.question_text:
An AWS Lambda function that Is running in a test environment is not working property. However, there is no error associated with the Lambda function in the Amazon CloudWatch logs for the account. The Lambda function's permissions do not include a resource-based policy. The Lambda function's execution role has properly configured trust relationships and has no permissions policies attached.

Which action should a developer take to allow logs for the Lambda function to appear in CloudWatch?

choices.A: Attach the AWSLambda8asicExecutionRole managed policy to the Lambda function's execution role.
choices.B: Set the AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole managed policy as the Lambda function's resource-based policy.
choices.D: Set the CloudWatchLambdaInsightsExecutionRolePolicy managed policy as the Lambda function's resource-based policy.
choices.C: Attach the CloudWatchLambdaInsightsExecutionRolePolicy managed policy to the Lambda function's execution role.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole allows the lambda function to write logs to CloudWatch

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-managed-policy/latest/reference/AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole.html

Selected Answer: A
It should be A
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/aws-managed-policy/latest/reference/AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole.html

Selected Answer: C
C it should be

Selected Answer: C
C is best option in my opinion.

comments.content:
The question, as it is written, says that the problem is that no logs are written.

The AWSLambdaBasicExecution role has, on Resource *, CreateLogGroup, CreateLogStream, PutLogEvents.

CloudWatchLambdaInsightsExecutionRolePolicy has those exact same permissions, but narrows PutLogStream and PutLogEvents to log-group:/aws/lambda-insights, and Lambda Insights is a tool not mentioned in the question. It would be overkill for the stated problem, and Lambda by default would not try to log to that location-- so the permission would be wasted. https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/monitoring-insights.html#monitoring-insights-enabling-programmatically

So yes, stop agreeing on the wrong answer.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Stop agreeing on wrong answers.
Option A is not correct because attaching the AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole policy to the Lambda function's execution role is not related to CloudWatch logs. This policy only grants the basic permissions needed for the Lambda function to run, such as writing to CloudWatch Logs and creating and deleting network interfaces.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A - AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole grants permissions to upload logs to CloudWatch

Selected Answer: A
I agree

Sorry my bad , its A
AWSLambdaBasicExecutionRole grants permissions to upload logs to CloudWatch.

C
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/lambda-intro-execution-role.html

choices.C: Scale vertically by resizing the EC2 instances.

choices.B: Host the application code on AWS Lambda.
choices.D: Create an Amazon CloudFront distribution to cache the static content.

Yep I agree DE are the only possible correct values. It's possible to write static data to S3 in order to improve the performance and we can enable CloudFormation in order to enable cache on the edges and ensure a better experience for user "across the world"

Selected Answer: DE
D and E are the best options.

Selected Answer: DE
D & E. EC2 is not the best place to store static content. Keep them on S3 and serve via CloudFront.

Selected Answer: DE
Agree with provided answers

questions.question_text:
A company's website runs on an Amazon EC2 instance and uses Auto Scaling to scale the environment during peak times. Website users across the world are experiencing high latency due to static content on the EC2 instance, even during non-peak hours.

Which combination of steps will resolve the latency issue? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I would say create read replicas but given the options B is obviously the right one. It is possible to configure ElasticCache on RDS MySQL DB to improve performance
This question was on the exam today (Feb 2023)

Selected Answer: B
B is correct. Elasticache is what you need. You might think "why not C"? Well actually it doesn't matter in this scenario whether you use Redis or Memcached, as both would work. However, C is there to distract you because it says deploy Memcached "on an EC2" , which would be meaningless. Hence, just deploying Elasticache with Redis is the answer.
B it is

Selected Answer: B
B it is.

Selected Answer: B
Agreed

Selected Answer: B
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/28851-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-265/

B
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/28851-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-265/

questions.question_text:
An application is experiencing performance issues based on increased demand. This increased demand is on read-only historical records pulled from an Amazon RDS-hosted database with custom views and queries. A developer must improve performance without changing the database structure.

Which approach will improve performance and MINIMIZE management overhead?

choices.A: Deploy Amazon DynamoDB, move all the data, and point to DynamoDB.
choices.D: Deploy Amazon DynamoDB Accelerator (DAX) on Amazon RDS to improve cache performance.
choices.B: Deploy Amazon ElastiCache for Red is and cache the data for the application.
choices.C: Deploy Memcached on Amazon EC2 and cache the data for the application.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Elastic Load Balancer can be Application or Network. Since the protocol is HTTP/HTTPS, we are talking about ALB. Then, if we retrieve the IP directly from the request we always receive the load balancer IP. To obtain the client IP address, we have to read "X-Forwarder-For" from the header. So the answer A is the correct one.

Selected Answer: A
Application load balancer supports HTTP/HTTPS. 
Questions states that the solution must access the client IP addresses. ALB passes the client's IP address in the header under "X-Forwarded-For". The answer is A.

Selected Answer: A
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/69344-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-376/

A
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/69344-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-376/

questions.question_text:
A company is planning to deploy an application on AWS behind an Elastic Load Balancer. The application uses an HTTP/HTTPS listener and must access the client IP addresses.

Which load-balancing solution meets these requirements?

choices.A: Use an Application Load Balancer and the X-Forwarded-For headers.
choices.C: Use an Application Load Balancer. Register the targets by the instance ID.
choices.B: Use a Network Load Balancer (NLB). Enable proxy protocol support on the NLB and the target application.
choices.D: Use a Network Load Balancer and the X-Forwarded-For headers.

questions.question_text:
A developer has setup an Amazon Kinesis Stream with 4 shards to ingest a maximum of 2500 records per second. A Lambda function has been configured to process these records.

In which order will these records be processed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
according to kinesis streaming option C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is definitely correct because the data in each shard are ordered but the shards can be retrieved in casual order.

Selected Answer: C
C
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/5413-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-43/

Selected Answer: C
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/5413-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-43/

Selected Answer: C
C is the correct answer

C
https://www.examtopics.com/discussions/amazon/view/5413-exam-aws-certified-developer-associate-topic-1-question-43/

choices.C: Lambda will receive each record in the exact order it was placed into the shard following a FIFO (first-in, first-out) method. There is no guarantee of order across shards.
choices.A: Lambda will receive each record in the reverse order it was placed into the stream following a LIFO (last-in, first-out) method.
choices.B: Lambda will receive each record in the exact order it was placed into the stream following a FIFO (first-in, first-out) method.
choices.D: The developer can select FIFO (first-in, first-out), LIFO (last-in, first-out), random, or request specific record using the getRecords API.
